Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Nonlocal Interfaces in Biological Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the development of mathematical tools for understanding phenomena caused by the interactions among biological interfaces. An interface is a transition between regions in a system, each exhibiting different biological properties. The natural world displays a vast gallery of organized systems characterized by complex interface dynamics, including the edges of growing tumors or bacterial colonies, the surface of a growing, hollow embryo, or the transition region between high and low electrical activity in a beating heart. This project will investigate biological systems that involve interfaces with interactions on long length-scales; the behaviors of these interfaces have properties which cannot be predicted by purely local dynamics, as when a bubble popping far away allows other bubbles to grow. The new tools developed will be validated through experimentation with bacterial biofilms and human organoids. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in the research at both California State University-Long Beach and Montana State University, and Native American students will be recruited using collaborative outreach programs in existence at Montana State University.

The investigation will focus on studying complex systems characterized by a collection of mutually interacting curves or surfaces. These nonlocal mutual interactions can produce a variety of pattern forming behaviors that typically do not occur in classical interfacial models. For example, nonlocal interfacial models exhibit arrested fronts, which are stationary, dynamically stable interfaces between quasi-homogeneous regions in a complex system. The interactions between certain strains of bacteria provide a concrete instance of such fronts. The evolution of genetically identical sibling colonies lead to competition between these colonies, and this competition produces a collection of mutually interacting interfaces (i.e. the boundary of each colony) that eventually arrest in regions of sibling-sibling competition. The project will introduce a first-principle modeling framework for nonlocal interfaces that offers reduced model complexity from both an analytical and computational perspective. Despite the relative simplicity of this framework, its specific instances still capture the essential pattern forming mechanisms in a variety of biological systems. As a consequence, research under the award will focus on validating this overall approach via experimental predictions in several biological systems. This approach to understanding nonlocal pattern formation appears new at the level of generality introduced in the project, and it opens the door to numerous explorations of the mathematical behavior of the framework and of its applications for different experimental systems. The major aim is to provide researchers with a comparatively flexible, minimalistic framework to study arrested fronts and other interfacial phenomena.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on the design and validation of models for mutually interacting nonlocal interfaces, as well as numerical algorithms for simulating these models.

In broad terms, an interface is simply a region of transition between different states in a physical or biological system. The edge of a growing bacteria colony serves as an example of a biological interface. It represents the transition between the interior of the colony itself and the surrounding environment, such as a plate of agar, of the colony. If the interfaces in such a system surround nearly-homogeneous regions then it becomes reasonable to model only the interfaces themselves. For instance, if concentrations in the interior of a bacteria colony are nearly constant then the growth of the colony is well-described by knowing only the location of the interface; modeling the colony interior is unnecessary.

The proposal focused on such models characterized by the presence of several interfaces that interact mutually through non-local effects. Continuing the example, certain bacteria can secrete antibacterial compounds to inhibit the growth of competing colonies. The secretion of one colony affects the growth of any other, so the interfaces are mutually interacting. Any point on the interface of one colony potentially affects other colonies via secretion that causes an effective repulsion. The magnitude of this repulsion decreases as a function of distance. A mechanism of this type is a typical example of a distance-dependent, non-local interaction between interfaces.

Models including such effects are a helpful, but under-studied, tool for understanding pattern formation in biological systems. Work during the proposal therefore focused on 1) developing an analytical foundation for the rigorous mathematical analysis of general nonlocal curve flows, and 2) developing numerical algorithms, and associated code, for simulating the dynamics of such flows. The mathematical properties of related flows have been well-studied, but the class of models that allow for different interfaces to interact with each other has received relatively little attention. From an analytical point-of-view, results of the project show that a wide range of non-local forcing effects still give rise to a mathematically well-behaved dynamic. This is useful from a modeling practitioner's point of view, as it allows them to confidently include quite general non-local effects while still retaining a model that is mathematically well-defined.

Additional work under the project developed analytical tools for determining whether non-local models preserve interfaces. That is, if a collection of mutually interacting interfaces are well-formed at time zero, are they still well-formed at later times? Interfaces driven by nonlocal interfacial flow can potentially self-intersect, and/or establish stationary complex shapes that do not necessarily become circular. This is quantified via the mathematical notion of distortion. On one hand, the distortion of some interfaces may start out finite, but become infinite in finite time. On the other hand, even for the same choice of model parameters the distortion of other interfaces may remain finite for all time. This dynamical diversity stands in sharp contrast to more standard interfacial flows that have well-understood and relatively homogeneous long-term behavior. Nevertheless, it is precisely this variety of dynamic behaviors that makes these systems useful for modeling real world phenomena. The mathematical tools developed allow for an understanding of how the distortion of interfaces evolves in time for various model instances. Results of the project include also include code implementing an efficient and robust numerical scheme, which will allow other researchers to utilize and explore non-local interfacial models in their own simulations.
